messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level B1

Text saved: "The Life of Pi" tells the amazing story of a teenage boy from India called Pi. After his ship sinks, he gets trapped in a small boat in the Pacific Ocean with a dangerous tiger. It is the third book by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and it was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies all over the world, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Martel's father worked for the government in other countries, so as a child, he lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico.

metadata.feedback_text: The submission is an instant FAIL. The primary reason is a violation of the Stage 1 CEFR Compliance Check. The `CEFR_Classifier_Result` was 'A2', which does not match the required target CEFR level.

Text saved: "The Life of Pi" tells the amazing story of a teenage boy from India called Pi, who gets trapped in a small boat in the Pacific Ocean with a dangerous tiger after his ship sinks. The book, which is the third one by the Canadian author Yann Martel, was published in 2001. Since then, it has sold over seven million copies all over the world, won several prizes and been translated into 41 languages. Because Martel's father worked for the government in other countries, he lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico as a child.

metadata.feedback_text: The submission has been marked as FAIL because it did not pass the Preliminary Metrics Check. The text was classified at an A2 level, which is below the required B1 target. While the text is clear and factually accurate, its linguistic complexity, primarily using A1 and A2 vocabulary and sentence structures, does not demonstrate the competence expected at the B1 level.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level B1

Text saved: "The Life of Pi" tells the extraordinary story of an Indian teenager named Pi, who becomes shipwrecked and finds himself trapped in a lifeboat on the Pacific Ocean with a ferocious tiger. The book, which was published in 2001, is the third one by the Canadian author Yann Martel, and since then it has sold over seven million copies worldwide, won several prizes, and been translated into 41 languages. The author, Yann Martel, is the son of a diplomat, and as a result, he lived in Costa Rica, Canada, France and Mexico when he was a child.

metadata.feedback_text: This is an excellent B1 submission. Your ability to construct long, complex sentences is a clear strength. For example, you correctly used a relative clause ('which was published in 2001') and a connector of result ('as a result') to link ideas smoothly and accurately. The vocabulary is appropriate for the level, and all facts from the original text have been preserved perfectly. This text fully demonstrates the B1 competence to write connected text.
